Woolf herself was the pioneer of feminist
literary criticism in the twentieth century.

49.text:
She was hugely preoccupied throughout her
writing life with the role of women in history

57.text:
and with the relationship of women and fiction,
and writing continuously about the practice

63.text:
and the difficulties of women’s writing
and of writing as a woman – in her diaries,

66.text:
in letters, and in numerous reviews and essays,
all of which have been published and are readily

69.text:
available to us. Woolf is a gift, basically,
to any undergraduate or scholar, because she

72.text:
tells us so much about the genesis and processes
of her writing, all of which can be drawn

74.text: into our understanding of her work.

75.text:
A Room of One’s Own was published in 1929,
and makes a number of key arguments, in particular:

85.text:
About the social and economic conditions necessary
for writing, and the fact that women have

92.text:
been denied these for much of literary history;
About the consequent lack of a tradition of

95.text:
women’s writing for those women beginning
to write in the nineteenth and early twentieth

98.text:
centuries to draw upon;
About the concept of a ‘female sentence’,

106.text:
or in other words a style and subject matter
that Woolf regards as articulating women’s

110.text:
voice and values, and that is identifiably
different to that of male writers [and this

115.text:
is something that I will talk more about in
the last part of this mini lecture];

121.text:
And finally about the ideal, and it is only
an ideal, that she has for an androgynous

127.text:
aesthetic, in which an author would be able

142.text:
What I want to do today is to introduce you
to the style and approach of the essay, and

152.text:
then to look particularly at what Woolf says
about the possibilities for women’s fiction

160.text:
in the twentieth century and implicitly perhaps,
her own aims as a novelist.

165.text:
A Room of One’s Own grew out of two lectures
that Woolf was invited to give on ‘Women

174.text:
and Fiction’ to the two women’s colleges
at Cambridge – Newnham and Girton – in

181.text:
1928. Woolf was by now the author of six novels,
and the colleges could be forgiven for thinking

187.text:
that this was a subject that she would feel
confident talking about – and of course

193.text:
she is, but not perhaps in the conventional
way that she imagines they expect. And she

202.text:
begins by refusing quite bluntly to offer
what she recognizes is generally assumed to

210.text:
be the object of a university lecture – to
impart a series of ‘facts’ for students

216.text: to scribble down and take away. This is Woolf:

224.text:
When you asked me to speak about women and
fiction I sat down on the banks of a river

229.text:
and began to wonder what the words meant.
They might mean simply a few remarks about

233.text:
Fanny Burney; a few more about Jane Austen;
a tribute to the Brontës and a sketch of

238.text:
Haworth Parsonage under snow; some witticisms
if possible about Miss Mitford; a respectful

243.text:
allusion to George Eliot; a reference to Mrs
Gaskell and one would have done. But at second

250.text:
sight the words seemed not so simple. The
title women and fiction might mean, and you

255.text:
may have meant it to mean, women and what
they are like, or it might mean women and

260.text:
the fiction that they write; or it might mean
women and the fiction that is written about

265.text:
them, or it might mean that somehow all three
are inextricably mixed together and you want

271.text:
me to consider them in that light. But when
I began to consider the subject in this last

276.text:
way, which seemed the most interesting, I
soon saw that it had one fatal drawback. I

282.text:
should never be able to come to a conclusion.
I should never be able to fulfil what is,

287.text:
I understand, the first duty of a lecturer
to hand you after an hour’s discourse a

292.text:
nugget of pure truth to wrap up between the
pages of your notebooks and keep on the mantelpiece

298.text:
Of course it is soon clear that not only is
Woolf suspicious of so-called ‘nuggets of

306.text:
truth’, but also that she wants the students
listening to her to do more than simply note

312.text:
down a few facts to regurgitate in an essay
or exam. Women and fiction, she says ‘remain,

321.text:
so far as I am concerned, unsolved problems’
– and she invites her audience to join her,

330.text:
to engage with her, in exploring those problems,
to follow her train of thought as she researches,

338.text:
muses and ponders over the history of women’s
writing.

346.text:
To do so she divests herself of the authoritative
identity ‘Virginia Woolf, woman writer’,

352.text:
and takes on the voice of a persona called
‘Mary’, who has been invited to give a

358.text:
similar lecture to a thinly fictionalized
women’s college ‘Fernham’, at a thinly

365.text:
fictionalized university ‘Oxbridge’, and
who actually spends the whole of the rest

369.text:
of the essay researching and worrying about
what she is going to say.

372.text:
So the essay reopens, as it were, in the voice
of Mary, as she is sat by a river that runs

380.text:
along the edge of a male college, where she
has been invited for lunch. She is trying

385.text:
to plan her lecture and suddenly she senses/glimpses
the beginnings of a thought (thoughts, and

397.text:
characters, are always very ephemeral in Woolf’s
writing – always trying to slip away from

408.text:
her, difficult to catch). As she 
is sort of metaphorically chasing it, still

437.text:
not fully formed in her mind, she walks unconsciously
across the college grass, to be immediately

453.text:
stopped by a college official rushing towards
her – only male scholars can walk on the

467.text:
grass, women visitors must keep to the path.
The thought, in the meantime, has escaped.

489.text:
She then decides to go to the library, to
look up a manuscript, but she is stopped at

498.text:
the door: ‘instantly there issued, like
a guardian angel barring the way with a flutter

506.text:
of black gown instead of white wings, a deprecating,
silvery, kindly gentleman, who regretted in

512.text:
a low voice as he waved me back that ladies
are only admitted to the library if accompanied

517.text:
by a Fellow of the College or furnished with
a letter of introduction’. Mary is angry

523.text:
– but as she says: ‘That a famous library
has been cursed by a woman, is a matter of

529.text:
complete indifference to a famous library’
…

532.text:
Now Woolf is a very skilful essayist and A
Room of One’s Own continues in exactly this

538.text:
way – accessible, very conversational in
tone, very funny, very impassioned, very enticing

543.text:
to read, deeply engaging. It comments on real
women writers, such as Aphra Benn, Jane Austen

552.text:
and Charlotte Bronte, but it is also full
of anecdotes, dramatized stories, satiric

561.text:
and tragic characters. It is part criticism,
part fiction, part history, part biography,

570.text:
part autobiography – and in this way Woolf
is able to introduce quite complex theoretical

580.text:
ideas in a way that is never alienating, and
polemical feminist ones in a manner that seems

587.text:
self-deprecating. Nevertheless she expected
a negative response amongst the largely male

593.text:
critical institution, and awaited reviews
with considerable nervousness: ‘I shall

597.text:
be attacked for a feminist’, she noted in
her diary, ‘I am afraid it will not be taken

606.text:
Woolf is very wary of making any definitive
assertions about women’s writing, or at

613.text:
least in terms of its style or form. Indeed
much of the essay is taken up with her reflections

620.text:
on the lack of women’s writing over the
history of English literature, and the fact

625.text:
that there are so few women writers. The reason
for this, she argues very overtly, is because

632.text:
fiction is not just the result of genius,
but of material circumstance.

638.text:
Prior to the nineteenth century, she argues,
the demands of the domestic household, the

647.text:
laws that denied married women ownership of
funds or property, a lack of educational opportunity,

653.text:
made it almost impossible for a woman to take
up writing as a profession.

657.text:
The creative voice of even the most gifted
women would have remained mute, through want

667.text:
Women’s economic, social and political powerlessness,
she declares, has then also resulted in centuries

678.text:
of cultural representation that privilege
things regarded important by men, and that

684.text:
have conversely marginalised female experience.
As Mary browses the shelves of the British

695.text:
Library, she looks for the ways in which women
are represented, or not, in the books collected

704.text:
there. History books, she finds, concentrate
on the ‘great movements’ of government,

709.text:
empire or scientific revolution, and are dominated
by the actions and values of men. Fiction

717.text:
by contrast seems to mythologise female characters
in a manner that bears little relation to

726.text:
reality. This is Mary [Woolf]: ‘Some of
the most inspired words, some of the most

732.text:
profound thoughts in literature fall from
her lips’, she is talking of women characters

736.text:
in the plays of Shakespeare, but ‘in real
life she could hardly read, could scarcely

742.text: spell, and was the property of her husband’

751.text:
Woolf’s conclusion, is that women need time
and independence and freedom of thought if

764.text:
they are to be able to write – and that
these things depend on a certain degree of

769.text:
financial security and of private space – in
Woolf’s shorthand £500 a year and a room

781.text:
For Woolf this material basis is only the
start however - and here the focus of her

786.text:
argument shifts - from the material inequalities
that limited women’s opportunity to write,

794.text:
to the aesthetic problems of forging what
Woolf imagines as a more truly female mode

804.text:
of writing. This is what I want to focus on
for the remainder of the lecture.

815.text:
Even once a women has the money and a room
of her own to be able to write, Woolf thinks

822.text:
(and she writes about this in various essays
and reviews) the problem of ‘writing as

828.text:
a woman’, of actually creating fiction remains.
And here she seems to be suggesting that to

837.text:
write as a women has different problems and
different qualities, to writing as a man.

844.text:
In A Room of One’s Own, for example, Mary
thinks about women novelists of the nineteenth-century,

850.text:
such as the Brontes or George Eliot, and the
struggle they faced in writing, knowing that

858.text:
their work would be assessed according to
the cultural expectations of their gender,

866.text:
and pronounced sentimental or monstrous accordingly.
A woman writer might adopt a male pseudonym,

883.text:
for example, or wrote, so Mary/Woolf argues,
with a mixture of fear and anger, ‘admitting

891.text:
that she was “only a woman”, or protesting
that she was “as good as a man”’. It

904.text:
was only in the twentieth century, Woolf thought,
that the woman writer has begun to mould what

911.text:
she describes as ‘a prose style completely
expressive of her mind’.

913.text:
Now, to explore what she means by this, I
have given you a number of quotations on the

921.text:
Previously, Woolf argues, women writers have
only had available to them the language of

925.text:
men, and this is very different, in its values,
experience and interests, to that of women:

931.text:
‘it is obvious that the values of women
differ very often from the values which have

936.text:
been made by the other sex; naturally, this
is so. Yet it is the masculine values that

942.text:
prevail. Speaking crudely, football and sport
are ‘important’; the worship of fashion,

947.text:
the buying of clothes ‘trivial’. And these
values are inevitably transferred from life

952.text:
to fiction. This is an important book, the
critic assumes, because it deals with war.

958.text:
This is an insignificant book because it deals
with the feelings of women in a drawing- room.

963.text:
A scene in a battle-field is more important
than a scene in a shop – everywhere and

968.text: much more subtly the difference of value persists’.

974.text:
The challenge then becomes the writing of
a new kind of sentence – something Woolf

979.text:
had already been interested in for a long
time. In a review from 1920 we see her quoting

991.text:
the words of Bathsheba Everdene from Hardy’s
Far From the Madding Crowd:

996.text:
‘I have the feelings of a woman, but I have
only the language of men’. From that dilemma

1002.text:
[Woolf notes] arise infinite confusions and
complications. Energy has been liberated [she

1010.text:
is referring here to women over the age of
30 having been granted the vote in 1918],

1011.text:
but into what forms is it to flow? To try
the accepted forms, to discard the unfit,

1018.text:
to create others which are more fitting, is
a task that must be accomplished before there

1031.text:
This is Woolf’s feminist manifesto really
- once women have achieved independence, and

1054.text:
a right to property, education and their own
money, how do they fashion a life, and a voice,

1061.text:
that is true to their own sex and isn’t
just modeled on a status quo that has been

1066.text:
developed over centuries in accordance to
the lives and voices of men. It is a task

1073.text:
that we might think Woolf sets herself. In
her very first novel The Voyage Out, one of

1079.text:
the male characters, Terrence Hewett, a writer,
imagines writing a novel about the private

1091.text:
‘I’ve often walked about the streets where
people live all in a row and one house is

1096.text:
exactly like another house, and wondered what
on earth the women were doing inside,’ he

1101.text:
said. ‘Just consider: it’s the beginning
of the twentieth century, and until a few

1106.text:
years ago no woman had ever come out by herself
and said things at all. There it was going

1113.text:
on in the background, for all these thousands
of years, this curious silent unrepresented

1119.text:
life. Of course we’re always writing about
women – abusing them, or jeering at them,

1124.text:
or worshipping them; but it’s never come
from women themselves. I believe we still

1129.text:
don’t know in the least how they live, or
what they feel, or what they do precisely’.

1136.text:
Mrs Dalloway is a novel that in many ways
does exactly that, moving in and out of the

1142.text:
streams of consciousness of various female
characters of the course of one ordinary day.

1144.text:
In A Room of One’s Own, when ‘Mary’
picks up a first novel by an imaginary twentieth-century

1149.text:
writer Mary Carmichael, she is struck to find
that it is predominantly about relationships

1156.text:
between women, and about the minutiae of their
daily lives:

1162.text:
‘It ranged, too, very subtly and curiously,
amongst almost unknown or unrecorded things;

1171.text:
it lighted on small things and showed that
perhaps they were not so small after all.

1177.text:
It brought buried things to light and made
one wonder what need there had been to bury

1190.text:
‘I wanted to see [she says] how Mary Carmichael
set to work to catch those unrecorded gestures,

1198.text:
those unsaid or half-said words, which form
themselves, no more palpably than the shadows

1205.text:
of moths on the ceiling, when women are alone,
unlit by the capricious and coloured light

1211.text:
of the other sex’.
Thinking about the everyday life of London

1216.text:
around her, she imagines herself in conversation
with Mary, encouraging her to write the lives

1227.text: of women as they really are:

1233.text:
‘All these infinitely obscure lives remain
to be recorded, I said, addressing Mary Carmichael

1242.text:
as if she were present; and went on in thought
through the streets of London feeling in imagination

1249.text:
the pressure of dumbness, the accumulation
of unrecorded life, whether from the women

1254.text:
at street corners with their arms akimbo,
and the rings embedded in their fat swollen

1259.text:
fingers, talking with a gesticulation like
the swing of Shakespeare’s words; or from

1264.text:
the violet-sellers and match-sellers and old
crones stationed under doorways; or from drifting

1270.text:
girls whose faces, like waves in sun and cloud,
signal the coming of men and women and the

1275.text:
flickering lights of shop windows. All that
you will have to explore, I said to Mary Carmichael,

1282.text: holding your torch firm in your hand’.

1286.text:
Giving voice to the accumulation of unrecorded
life. This is perhaps the closest Woolf’s

1292.text:
comes to offering a manifesto for women’s
writing - it is what Terrence Hewet imagines

1298.text:
in The Voyage Out, what Woolf in part attempted
to do
